_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CITY OF ST. AUGUSTINE
RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The management of the wastewater treatment facility is a complex operation that includes a number of programs all directed toward continuous, uninterrupted treatment of the community's wastewater to the degree required by regulatory agencies.  If the supervisor and staff understand how an emergency can affect the wastewater treatment facility, and employees understand and are aware of their responsibilities in an emergency, its adverse effects can be eliminated or at least kept to a minimum. Procedures are described in the form of temporary and indefinite period shutdowns and alternate operating procedures, which should help, plant personnel cope with these emergencies. 

All wastewater treatment facilities experience such common problems as equipment breakdown, leaking pipes, plugged pipes, variations in the volume and quality of influent, etc.  The effects of these common problems may be cumulative, and they will affect the operation of the facility, if the necessary repairs or adjustments are not made.  However, the effects of these problems are different, in many respects, from those caused by a natural disaster or civil disorder.  Natural disasters, such as tornadoes, floods, hurricanes, and extreme cold, can cause emergencies for which the operations manager can prepare, but one cannot also overlook the increasing frequency of civil disorders like vandalism, sabotage, and riots, even outside of metropolitan areas.  No matter how well the facility is designed and operated, the potential for an emergency is always present.

Although natural disasters fall into many classifications and are obviously different from civil disorders, the potential damage to the facility is similar for most of these events.  Emergency operating plans that can be developed to cope with disasters have a common concern: damage assessment and emergency response to the damage to maintain the best facility operation possible.

To assist with meeting this goal, the treatment facility has developed procedures for responding to emergencies including a vulnerability analysis, hazardous chemical inventory, emergency notification, worst case scenarios, accidental releases and emergency response programs.

Policy Statement

The City of St. Augustine's major objective in developing a process safety management program for highly hazardous chemicals was to prevent unwanted releases of hazardous chemicals especially into locations, which could expose employees and others to serious hazards. An effective process safety management program requires a systematic approach to evaluating the whole process. Using this approach the process design, process technology, operational and maintenance activities and procedures, non-routine activities and procedures, emergency preparedness plans and procedures, training programs, and other elements which impact the process are all addressed in the City's process safety management program. The various lines of defense that have been incorporated into the design and operation of the process to prevent or mitigate the release of hazardous chemicals was evaluated and strengthened to assure their effectiveness at each level. The process safety management program is a proactive identification, evaluation and mitigation or prevention of chemical releases that could occur as a result of failures in process, procedures or equipment. The process safety management program targets highly hazardous chemicals that have the potential to cause a catastrophic incident. This program as a whole is designed to aid the City in its efforts to prevent or mitigate episodic chemical releases that could lead to a catastrophe in the workplace and possibly to the surrounding community. To control these types of hazards, the City has attained the necessary expertise, experiences, judgement and proactive initiative within their workforce to properly implement and maintain an effective process

safety management program as envisioned in the OSHA standard. The OSHA standard is required by the Clean Air Act Amendments, as is the Environmental Protection Agency's Risk Management Plan. The City, who merged the two sets of requirements into their process safety management program, will better assure full compliance with each as well as enhancing their relationship with the local community. 


The Facility and Regulated Substances

The St. Augustine Wastewater Treatment Plant No. 1 has been expanded and renovated to meet the stringent effluent quality requirements of today and of the near future.  An Operation and Maintenance Manual has been prepared to provide understanding and guidance in the operation and maintenance of the St. Augustine facility.  Its purpose is to provide the data needed by the plant personnel to obtain and maintain effective and efficient treatment of the community's wastewater.

Proper operation of the facilities is obtained by understanding, monitoring, and controlling the equipment and the treatment processes.  Toward this end, descriptions and functions of the equipment are detailed; operational procedures and laboratory controls are specified; and preventive maintenance data is provided.

Equipment failure is likely at any time during the operation of a wastewater treatment facility.  Equipment failure during an emergency compounds the problem.  Various protective measures include mutual aid agreements for spare parts, equipment, and supplies and an evaluation of specialized assistance available from sanitary engineers, - chemists, maintenance experts, and other operators.  Equipment failure response scenarios for the process facilities of the plant are provided for in the facility's Operation and Maintenance Manuals.

General Information on Chlorine:

CHLORINE is a greenish-yellow gas with a bleach-like choking odor and is a chemical element used in the manufacture of solvents, insecticides, bleaching of paper, pulp and fabrics, disi

nfecting and water purification.
FIRE DATA:  May ignite other combustibles. Non-flammable. Most combustibles will burn in chlorine forming irritating and toxic gases.
EXPLOSIVE DATA: Vapor explosion hazard indoors, outdoors, or in sewers.  Containers may explode in heat of fire.  Reacts explosively or forms explosive compounds with acetylene, turpentine, ether, ammonia, fuels, hydrogen and finely divided metals.
REACTIVE DATA:  When mixed with ammonia will form a lethal gas.  When mixed with water will form a corrosive acid (HC1). Will react at high temperatures with metals. Copper will burn spontaneously.
Strong oxidizer.
NEUTRALIZING AGENTS:
Chlorine can be absorbed into an alkaline solution, i.e., caustic soda, caustic potash, lime, etc.

General information on Sulfur Dioxide:

SULFUR DIOXIDE is a toxic, irritating, colorless gas soluble in water, alcohol and ether, with a sharp pungent odor, used as a  chemical intermediate, in artificial ice, paper pulping, ore refining and as a solvent, disinfective and in fumigating.

Consequence if People are exposed:                                              
Contact with fumes may cause burns to skin and eyes with possible loss of vision- -
Contact with liquid may cause frostbite. May be harmful if inhaled: may cause  pulmonary edema and respiratory paralysis.
Consequences for Property:  Incompatible with metals-
Consequence of Environmental Exposure:  Runoff from fire control or dilution water may cause
Pollution:Harmful to aquatic life.                 
Dangerous air contaminant and constituent of smog.

Chlorine gas is contained in 2,000-pound steel cylinders and sulfur dioxide gas is contained in 150 steel cylinders; both chemicals are stored in the Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide Handling Facility located in the eastern section of the plant.  Any leak of chlorine is very dangerous to personnel and to the environment.  Sulfur dioxide is less toxic than chlorine but is still as harmful to people and the environment.  Cau

tion should always be exercised when handling either chlorine or sulfur dioxide equipment. A complete guide to the use, storage and operating procedures is described in the facility's Process Safety Management, Manual of Practice and the facility's Operation and Maintenance Manual.

The St. Augustine wastewater treatment facility must be viewed as a dynamic means of collecting, treating, and discharging wastewater that meets regulatory agency requirements, regardless of conditions.  Significant operating differences are encountered under extreme emergency conditions resulting from a tornado, a flood, or a serious civil disorder or other disaster. It is toward these circumstances that a vulnerability assessment is directed.

The wastewater treatment and conveyance system -- in terms of fixed or physical facilities -- can be described by:


Collection system
Force mains and interceptors
Treatment facilities

Each of these facilities is complex, including hundreds or even thousands of individual components.  However, to spend money on any physical facility is of no use to the City without achieving acceptable treatment of wastewater. Even with adequate physical facilities, the wastewater treatment system	is incapable of meeting its responsibility to the community without proper operation.  Proper operation requires:

Trained personnel
Power
Materials and supplies
Communications

Managers and operators must understand both the strengths and weaknesses of an individual system in relation to specific anticipated or design emergencies before attempting to draft emergency operational plans.  In considering an emergency or disaster at a wastewater treatment facility, several additional aspects are involved: 

Determining the status of the system following the disaster
Establishing immediate recovery objectives
Designing a feasible plan for achieving objectives 
Implementing the plan of action
Coordinating activities

Making decisions is an essential part of the total process

.  An important role of an emergency plan is to reduce the number of decisions that must be made under emergency conditions by providing for orderly initiation and implementation of predetermined remedial and restoration measures.

Worst Case and Alternative Scenarios

The City of St. Augustine has implemented changes in the chlorination and sulfonation systems to prevent catastrophic spills from occurring.  The systems that are now in place has reduced the amount of chlorine being released from 8,000 pounds to 2,000 pounds, and will still function more efficiently than the previous system.  The sulfonation system has also undergone a complete replacement, which has reduced the amount of chemical release from 900 pounds to 150 pounds.  The system is constantly monitored by detectors inside the process building and at the outside storage area.  These monitors have an audible alarm as well as being connected to the facility's telemetry system.

The area of impact or vulnerability zone of these chemicals in case of a spill has been calculated using the USEPA RMP Submit program.  

Worst Case Scenario- Chlorine - 0.9 miles diameter effecting an estimated population of  2,998
Worst Case Scenario- Sulfur Dioxide - 0.2 miles diameter effecting an estimated population of  9
The Alternative Scenario- Chlorine - 0.5 miles diameter effecting an estimated population of  619
The Alternative Scenario- Sulfur Dioxide- 0.1 miles diameter effecting an estimated population of  0

The areas of concern impacts residential neighborhoods, commercial facilities, recreational facilities, medical facilities, downtown St. Augustine, and the southern areas of the City's Historic District.

The population affected by the spill was calculated using information supplied by the St. Johns County Tax Collector Office.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program

The City of St. Augustine is regulated by the Clean Air Act (CAA), Section 112(r), issued in June 1996.  The City also is regulated by

Title 40 CFR Part 68 and Title 29 CFR 1910.119 governing Process Safety Management.

The City of St. Augustine has implemented a Process Safety Management, Manual of Practice.  This manual describes the employee participation, visitor training and entry control, process safety information, hazard analysis, risk analysis, process hazards, process flow diagrams, trouble shooting the process, operating procedures, training program, mechanical integrity, fire prevention and protection, management of change, incident/accident investigation emergency planning and response, compliance safety audits, contractor program and safety procedures, and pre-startup safety reviews.

Five Year Accident History 

The City of St. Augustine has not had a chemical spill in the past five years.

Emergency Response Program

The City of St. Augustine share the responsibility of responding to hazardous material spills or releases.

Responsibilities shared by the county and City of St. Augustine fire departments include:

a) Respond to, investigate, and assume direct control of the management of hazardous material incident scenes occurring within its jurisdiction.

b) Determine the type and nature of the hazardous material involved.

c) Determine the necessity for an evacuation, issue evacuation orders when appropriate, and identify the vulnerable zone to be evacuated.

d) Notify the emergency communication center, Office of Emergency Management, which will make proper notification to federal and state agencies as required by federal and state laws.

e) Request assistance from appropriate federal and state agencies through the Director of Public Safety.

f) Initiate request for assistance from appropriate agencies necessary to neutralize and/or contain the hazardous materials involved.

g) Give full cooperation to assisting agencies involved in determining action to be taken to contain the hazardous material and restore the area to normal.

h) Provide vehicle washdown and monitoring, when nec

essary, at prescribed locations and in a manner consistent with Florida Department of Environmental Protection and/or Health Department direction.  

Outside assistance to assure complete readiness including mutual aid agreements and contracts with outside organizations for specialized assistance.

Special emphasis should be placed on keeping the facility safe from sabotage, vandalism,	
or trespassers. The equipment at the treatment plant represents a substantial investment on the part of the citizens of St. Augustine and warrants protection by plant personnel.  Trespassers unfamiliar with the facilities could easily fall into a tank and drown.

Doors are required to be closed and locked according to policies set up by plant administrators.  Those personnel working in the evening or at night leave the gate locked to protect themselves from intruders.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Currently the City has invested thousands of dollars in the most advanced and safest chlorination/dechlorination equipment on the market.  The City will always look to the best available technology to improve the safety and operation of its systems to the benefit of the citizens of St. Augustine.  Alternative methods of disenfection are currently being considered.
